posts.sub: Welcome to /his/ - History & Humanities
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

पितुर्मातुरध्या ये समस्वरन्नृचा शोचन्तः संदहन्तो अव्रतान् । इन्द्रद्विष्टामप धमन्ति मायया त्वचमसिक्नीं भूमनो दिवस्परि ॥

इन्द्रद्विष्टामप - Indra's hated away
धमन्ति - blow (like a storm)

भूमनो - earth
दिवस्परि - from heaven
Thus, the final translation would be:
Drive away Indra's hated from heaven and earth, those ensnared by the illusory nature of reality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To listen to the tape is a spectacularly horrific experience. Jones, who is widely known to be a powerful speaker, is visibly fatigued. His tone is tired, but reeks of ersatz sincerity. His voice does not reach high volumes and he does not employ rowdy techniques; he does not want to ignite the crowd into a frenzy. Rather, he is attempting to calm them. In fact, the audience responds to his comments with applause and cheers, but his voice remains stable and controlled. The audience interjects with loud comments, but his mode of operation is unnervingly tranquil.

Gone are the excited qualities of his previous sermons, the likes of which can be compared to Southern Baptist preaching techniques. He has replaced agitating tactics with an approach that suggests peace and all-knowing authority. Toward the end of the tape, his voice is reminiscent of a father reading a story to his children before bed. As the children in the background of the tape cease crying and his final words, “We didn’t commit suicide. We committed an act of revolutionary suicide protesting the conditions of an inhumane world,” are said, we are left with only eerie meditation music playing.

Unfortunately, it is a well-documented truth that Jones’ speech was effective, so effective that by the end of the tape, the entire audience performed the action that Jones wanted them to. This is a unique rhetorical study because the result of this speech was not a campaign vote or a product purchased. His manipulations caused hundreds of deaths that day. It is unthinkable to imagine that one man could be responsible for the deaths of these people, but through rhetorical analysis, we can uncover the violently compelling rhetorical techniques that Jones had perfected throughout his career.

My 2 cents. No it did not, that contributed to it obviously but in was in pop culture before and after and it all contains folktale elements like elves, goblins etc. Not just folktales, but literature was produced throughout all the ages.
>_During the middle ages_: Many folktale novels with fantastical elements, focussed on Charlemagne, King Arthur etc.*. Many knight romances which would inspire Chivalry in the Romantic period insertion later was already written down.
>Rennaisance: Peak medieval idealism obsession. Spencer, Don Quixote etc.
>The Enlightenment: countless fairytales, too many to mention
>Romantacism: Brother's Grimm recorded folktales _that were always there and told for centuries_, their explicitly stated goal was to record true, raw examples of folklore which was best told by normal folk so they toured the German countryside to get it as opposed to writing fiction themselves. >What killed the Revolution?
The assembly line. Marx' analysis of industrial capitalism and all his conclusions about the exploitation of workers as a necessary consequence of capitalist competition rested on one assumption: that human labour was the only source of added value to products. Automation showed that there are alternative sources of added value, e.g. cars and TVs made by a precise assembly line of modern robots are more powerful and robust than cars and TVs made by a team of artisans, and they are produced in a cheaper and faster way. You could say that Ford made Marx obsolete overnight, in a way. So the only hope of post-Fordian tankies is to disrupt modern capitalist societies so much that workers desperately demand an alternative to free markets, and then establish an all-powerful totalitarian regime controlling prices, production, consumption, distribution and even private life that makes a return to free trade impossible, kind of like in DPR Korea.

The historian Bartolomé de las Casas, whose father traveled with Columbus on his second journey and who personally knew Columbus's sons,[nb 11] writes in chapter 2 of his Historia de las Indias:[17]

This distinguished man was from the Genoese nation, from some place in the province of Genoa; who he was, where he was born or what name he had in that place we do not know in truth, except that before he reached the Nation in which he arrived, he used to call himself Cristóbal Colombo de Terrarubia.

The historian Gonzalo Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés, writes that Domenico Colombo was the Admiral's father;[18] and in chapter 2, book 3 of his Historia general y natural de las Indias:[19]

Christopher Columbus, according to what I have learned from men of his nation, was originally from the province of Liguria, which is in Italy, where the city and the Seignory of Genoa stands: some say that he was from Savona, others that he was from a small place or village called Nervi, which is on the eastern seashore two leagues from the self same city of Genoa; but it is held to be more certain that he may have been originally from Cugurreo (Cogoleto) near the city of Genoa.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
New Mexico has not been a major user of capital punishment historically; just nine since the state took over executions from the county level in 1933 and only for particularly heinous crimes. Louis Young, an African-American, met his fate in New Mexico's electric chair on June 13, 1947 for the horrific slaying of a young white woman named Eloise Kennedy in Santa Fe. Young, aged 46 at his execution, had been convicted three times for burglary in his hometown of Houston, Texas. In 1943, he began a 10 year sentence for armed robbery when he tied an Albuquerque woman to a chair and demanded she give him the $110 she had with her or he'd kill her with an axe. In February 1944, a month into his sentence at the state pen, Young was made a trustee by the warden and assigned to work as a janitor at state police headquarters.

In this era it was common practice to use convicts for chain gangs or other labor tasks and New Mexico was no exception. An article in The Santa Fe New Mexican in 1944 made the shocking revelation that Governor John Dempsey had used convict labor to pave the driveway in front of the governor's mansion. A spokesman for Dempsey said that it was perfectly allowable to do that. In addition, Santa Fe is the only municipality in the state allowed to use convict labor for public works projects, a privilege granted in an 1889 statute, back when New Mexico was a territory.

On November 19, 1945, Louis Young had completed his morning chores at Police Chief Frank Young's apartment, and he was a frequent sight around the apartment complex on Bower Street. After he was done, he returned to the prison, ate dinner, and went to bed at his usual time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Eloise Kennedy was the 22 year old wife of Bud Kennedy, the son of a prominent Denver banking family. They had gotten married three years earlier, just before Bud went off to fight in WWII. Once he came home, they rented a place on Bower Street and Bud got a job as a bank teller. Their daughter Lynne was born in September 1945. The birth had been difficult and a few weeks afterwards, Eloise had not yet fully recovered. On November 19, she phoned her husband at work to tell him she was going to the dentist due to a toothache. Her neighbor Betty Flanagan knocked on the Kennedys' door that afternoon and got no response. She left and went into town to take care of some business. Another neighbor knocked on the door shortly afterwards and also got no response.

Around 5:30 PM, Bud Kennedy entered the apartment to find a scene of horror. Lynne was sound asleep in her crib, but Eloise lay face-down on the bathroom floor in a pool of blood. At first, Bud thought his wife succumbed to complications from her difficult childbirth and had suffered some kind of fatal hemorrhage. He called police and Eloise was taken into the city morgue. It was a little while longer before medical examiners found the ugly truth--she had multiple stab wounds to the neck, chest, and shoulder, which severed her jugular vein. There were bruises and a laceration in the vaginal area. Her pants were torn.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Police were bewildered and had no clue who could have done this. A variety of suspects and known sex criminals were looked into, but none produced any positive leads. On November 21, a 13 year old boy who lived near the apartments found a bent, blood-stained butcher knife in some bushes. Police chief Young, red-faced, recognized the knife as having come from his kitchen. He remembered Louis Young using it to cut up some meat in the kitchen a few weeks earlier. Young was awakened from his prison cell and taken for questioning. He insisted he was completely innocent in the slaying of Eloise Kennedy. When the chief's set of kitchen knives, minus one, was brought before him, still Young insisted he knew nothing. Next, the chief himself walked in with the bent, blood-covered butcher knife.

Young, crestfallen, finally broke down and confessed. He gave an oral statement, which was typed out for him as he was illiterate. He said that on November 19, he'd went to the Kennedys' apartment with the butcher knife and propositioned Eloise for sex. She refused and threatened to turn him in, so he stabbed her to death in a fit of fury. He had intended to rape her, but abandoned the attempt when he heard someone, possibly Betty Flanigan, calling to Eloise. Young split from the apartment and headed to Betty's, where he set to work waxing the floors. He had not even been considered a suspect initially.

When the police asked Young why he did it, he said he just wanted some "action" and didn't expect Eloise to turn him down, nor had he gone there with the intent of killing her.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After it came out that the murder weapon had been borrowed from the police chief's own kitchen, he quietly submitted his resignation. Mass public meetings were held to call for improved training of Santa Fe's police. Norman Shank, head of the city's chamber of commerce, wrote to J. Edgar Hoover asking for help. Hoover wrote back promising to send an FBI agent to help train Santa Fe police better. On the other hand, Mrs. Conception Jaramillo wrote a more cynical letter to The New Mexican declaring "many of us knew it or had been itching to say so for years, that most of the crime in Santa Fe was caused by Negros." There were considerable questions raised about allowing potentially dangerous convicts to roam in public freely.

In any event, Louis Young went on trial for the murder. Forensic examination of the crime scene found that the blood on the murder weapon and Young's prison coveralls was human, although DNA testing was more than 40 years away in 1945 so whose blood could not be determined. Curiously, several kinky black hairs found clutched in Eloise's hand turned out not to be Young's, but from the family dog.

A group of black civil rights activists were able to get a stay of execution and Young appealed to the state supreme court without success. They did not buy his claim that he just wanted sex and didn't expect Eloise to say no, since "everyone who knew Eloise" could not have imagined for a second that she would willingly sleep with a middle aged black convict. Young must have known the only way he was likely to get any "action" was taking it by force. In any case, he was executed June 13, 1947 after eating a handsome meal and singing black spirituals in his cell before he was led to New Mexico's Old Sparky.

I suppose it depends on what the process of creation is actually like. Is omnipotence the ability to do anything, or the ability to do anything any possible way? For example, if God is the external entity who produced logic, would he nonetheless accomplish his goals via logic?
If we can agree that logic is good because it provides reason, then we can agree that God must adhere to logical structures when creating the Universe.
It might be that genetic defects are a result of the overarching logic of creation, and the net good of that logic overcomes the evil of its consequences.
For example, if the good logic of god required that creation be very painful, and God was required(In order to uphold the good logic, but not because he is incapable of violating it), how much pain is God morally obligated to endure to be considered good by the standards of mortals? Could you even measure the amount of pain a God could suffer in the name of upholding the principles that underpin the cosmos?
Is God disqualified from omnipotence if a system of logic simply demands certain outcomes, and to defy them would be to destroy that system?

>>14494147
All of the major Chinese philosophies during the Hundred Schools of Thought by default all believe that God existed. The Chinese conception of God that is: Heaven and all the Shen (Deities & Spirits).

The thing is: they are irrelevant as far as we're concerned. Heaven and all the Deities are busy running all of creation. Heaven doesnt micromanage and order us around like the Semitic God does. It is ultimately up to Mankind, as a mortal earthbound spirit in charge of the mortal plane, to ponder & emulate the perfect harmony of Heaven.

This is what all the major Chinese philosophies and religions do. Confucianism for example seeks to emulate Heaven by ordering Human society to be more stable. Taoists seek to emulate Heaven by going with what already exists (i.e. Nature).

The worship of the deities in Folk Chinese, Taoist, and Confucian rites all largely focus on Honoring them, hoping that they might bless you, but not expecting any favors from them. Hence all of this "Good Fortune & Luck" business in Chinese religions/spiritualiy.

posts.com:
Are there any legitimate reasons for liberal governments to enforce laws prohibiting minors from engaging in consensual sexual activity with adults? All these laws manage to do is to stigmatize consensual sexual relations, fuel mass hysteria, and imprison innocent people.

Some claim that the existence of AOC laws prevents instances of child rape or other forms of sexual impropriety, but there is no empirical data supporting the claim that AOC laws lower the rates of or prevent child rape from occurring. For example, the Netherlands from 1989-2001 lowered their effective AOC to 12, and saw no increase in instances of sexual abuse involving minors, until reverting it to 16 under pressure from the United States.

It seems that antis operate under the presuppositions: (a) the majority of sexual relations between adults and minors are non-consensual, (b) minors are more likely to react negatively towards sex with adults, even though they may be willing participants, and (c) consensual sexual activity between an adult and a minor is likely to resolve in psychological harm for the minor.

But none of those premises are true. Sexual relations between adults and minors are not more likely to be non-consensual, people don't react more negatively to sexual activity according to a function of age, and there is absolutely no link between consensual sexual relationships and psychological harm.

Some claim that minors are incapable of consent for deontic reasons, therefore adult-minor sex is wrong irrespective of whether harm occurs, but all common forms of this argument ultimately rely on the condition that sexual activity between adults and minors are likely to result in harm, which is circular reasoning.

See Rind, B., Tromovitch, P. & Bauserman, R. (1998), Rind, B. (2022), Steever, E. E., Follette, V. M., & Naugle, A. E. (2001), and Constantine (1981).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14492915
>Why'd Staling do all his old buddies so dirty during the great purge, was he really just power hungry?
On the contrary. Stalin's goal was to consolidate Soviet power for generations to come. He wasn't your typical Latin American presidente-por-vida whose system falls apart as soon as he's deposed in a coup. Stalin knew perfectly that the USSR was a one of a kind experiment, and that it would have countless enemies that would work 24/7 to put it down, consciously and unconsciously. For example, the existence of a powerful Red Army was a threat to Soviet power - if the Army grew stronger than the Party, the USSR would end up as a military dictatorship in the best case, and a fragmented warlord wasteland like Mexico and China in the worst case. So Stalin made sure that the Red Army would always be in an inferior position to the Party by shooting all relevant commanders. And about old Bolsheviks, Stalin knew them well, he was aware tha he dealt with idealists in some cases (Berziņs), personal ambition in other cases (Kamenev) and finally pure omnicidal schizos (Trotsky). Stalin needed internal and external stability for the USSR to thrive, maybe to even exist. And those people were obvious obstacles in the path of Realpolitik and Socialism in One Country. You may blame Stalin for being true to his conviction that there are several things which are more important than personal liberty and individual rights, but if you believe that personal liberty and individual rights are sacred, you have a petit bourgeois mindset anyway.

More common than anyone will admit.

>One of the most common scenarios is a person discovering that they’re not genetically related to their father. This is known in the world of genetic genealogy as an NPE (‘non-paternity event’ or ‘not parent expected’), and it can be uncovered in a variety of ways – even if the father himself hasn’t tested. For example, maybe the database reveals unfamiliar paternal cousins, or consumers’ genetic ancestry results are markedly different from what they expected.

>Every person I interviewed described a seismic emotional reaction when they received unexpected results. ‘It was sort of like a death,’ Jason, a Midwestern 40something, told me, describing his initial response to the news that the man he believed was his father was not genetically related to him. ‘It’s like being unmoored,’ said Krista, a therapist in California who had her own NPE revelation and now helps others in the same position.

>The act of discovery doesn’t belong just to the person who spits into a tube or swabs her cheek. These surprises are common enough that the major testing companies train their customer service employees for calls of this nature. They also offer warnings to consumers when they test, along the lines of this one from 23andMe: ‘Though uncommon, unexpected relationships may be identified that could affect you and your family.’ Yet my interviews suggest that few people expect that these warnings will apply to them. After all, it would require a feat of extraordinary imagination, the conjuring of a kind of cognitive dissonance, to consider that there might be major, fundamental facts about your own family and identity that you don’t know. ‘I never ever expected this to happen – ever,’ said one geneticist. She’d written on the topic of DNA testing surprises less than a year before she discovered, by way of her own test, that she’d been conceived by sperm donor.

https://psyche.co/ideas/dna-testing-is-bringing-the-era-of-family-secrets-to-a-close

>How is this supposed to convince me? God hasn't revealed anything to me and just taking other people's word for it isn't enough for me so what am I supposed to do?

Well, I think we're dealing with two separate issues here. The first issue, which I addressed in my post, is how free will can be consistent with an omniscient God.

But the more basic and fundamental issue, as you rightly note, is the existence of God, or not.

Now, people come to belief in God in different ways. Quite often, it is through an overwhelming perception that the orderliness and evident design of the universe, and of humans and animals, could hardly have come about by chance, or as the end result of a primeval explosion (explosions generally result in disorder, not order). For instance, a man named Whittaker Chambers, a convinced atheist who was once quite famous as a Soviet spy, found himself coming to belief through an epiphany he experienced while holding his infant daughter at night:
>My eye came to rest on the delicate convolutions of her ear -- those intricate, perfect ears. The thought passed through my mind: "No, those ears were not created by any chance coming together of atoms in nature... They could have been created only by immense design.

It is hard to address this sort of thing without having a conversation. But I can tell you what worked for me, and that is to pray. Pray to the God who may or may not exist. Ask for the gift of faith, of belief. Ask that you might see -- for that is what faith is analogous to.

In my own case, it took a few years for that prayer to be answered. But in retrospect, that time was like a very gradual dawning of light upon a darkened landscape -- what was impenetrable and indistinct became illumined, and I could see.

Trust that God is good.

Conversion stories can be helpful, as guides of a sort. Here is one, about how the actor Alec Guinness came to faith: https://desuarchive.org/his/thread/14432034/#14432797

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14491579
>Can you explain this? I'm not familiar with the term.
Modality is the philosophical term for possibility and necessity. So, an argument commits the modal fallacy when it involves an invalid inference about something's possibility or necessity. Such an argument might take the following form:
1. Necessarily, if P then Q.
2. P.
3. Necessarily, Q.
This is a fallacious argument. You are only allowed to conclude that Q is the case, but not that it's necessarily the case. Now, this exact fallacious argument form is instantiated by the standard argument that free will is incompatible with divine foreknowledge. That argument goes:
1. Necessarily, if God knows that you will do X, then you will do X.
2. God knows that you will do X.
3. Necessarily, you will do X.
This argument is invalid because it commits the fallacy shown above. You are only allowed to conclude that you will do X, but not that you will necessarily do X. So, this argument fails to show that divine foreknowledge is incompatible with free will in the sense of the ability to do otherwise.

For me, these logic things are all self-contained. The conclusions are only based on the premises as stated. But now I'll be able to recognize what they mean by necessary.

I'm the anon who linked the Alec Guinness story. Like you, I was raised Catholic, then lost my faith. Like you, I never became a full-on atheist.

It's frustrating when it seems like God doesn't seem to answer or perhaps even hear our prayers. I am all too familiar with this experience. I know it provides but scant comfort, but I would encourage patience -- and indeed even to pray to God for the grace to be patient.

>I started critically examining the christian conception of God ... I haven't found that it hold up to scrutiny.

Eventually when, some years after my loss of faith, I again began to examine the Christian claim, I came across an argument that I found quite persuasive -- that is, the case for the Resurrection as based on the historical evidence.

This case is made out in two short books which, I think, complement each other. I highly recommend them both.

The better written of the two is Michael Green, Was Jesus Said He Was? It's out of print, but there are inexpensive used copies on Amazon and elsewhere.

The more detailed exposition of the evidence is made in Josh McDowell, More than a Carpenter.

Both books are quite good. Now, there are books that set out essentially the same argument in greater length and detail, if you were interested. The most notable of these, the big kahuna, is N.T. Wright, The Resurrection of the Son of God. An accessible and well-done video treatment is given in this series: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ErnJF_nwBk&list=PL1mr9ZTZb3TUYymBPce08oyuhnHLLkR_B, with episode #2 being the core and key episode.

I would also encourage you to read a couple of books of conversion stories, in particular, the aforementioned Surprised by Truth.

Also: Spiritual Journeys, edited by Robert Baram. Unfortunately out of print, but once again inexpensive used copies are available at Amazon* and elsewhere.

*https://www.amazon.com/Spiritual-Journeys-Robert-Baram/dp/0819868760/

Give Jesus another chance. Blessings, anon.

Odin comes from Wotan, which is a derivation of Godan.
tan/dan is a word ending which means roughly the same as el/elf/elv because it is the black-sea-celtic equivalent to the germanic word for river. (elb in germ and dwn in celt)

Thoth was a birdshaman during the greco-coptic period,- a period in which crimea exported large amounts of grain, and thus was also the reason why germanics and celts had such an early contact with the phoenecian alphabet version that is still in use today as opposed to the earlier versions,- because that is the version Thoth gave to the celto-germanic tradesmen.
My guess is that Wo/Go is some sort of word for bird/chirp/sound, because when put together with the wordending "dwn" that would make Odins name to mean "Flowing chirps", fitting with the theme of both Odin and Thoth linguistically.

>>14491331
>no because capitalism is by nature too efficient
The efficiency is in self optimisation of your capital and labour in order to maximise profit/production. This works because millions of individuals are better at deciding for themselves what the best use of their own labour/capital is rather than some central government run by power hungry midwits (communism).

However, there is a massive lag on this feedback loop system (e.g. unemployment periods, market closures, quaterly reports). This lag does not need to exist in the digital age. So therefore it's very likely we will develop some form of predictive control which will effectively move individual workers and capital _before_ they become redundant or inefficient. Such a system cannot possibly be controlled by people (communism) nor slow market feedback (capitalism), rather it is a combinatorial optimization problem that can only solved by A.I. and therefore represents a completely new system.

>tl;dr: In the near future you will have robots telling you where to go to make the most money, A.I. allocated index funds will increasingly outperform the market and become the only viable investment.
>You will own more and you will be happy.

>Even with my religious beliefs, I’ve been trying (and failing) to meditate
Properly meditating isn’t as easy as it sounds. Not because you have to sit in a special pose or do a certain gesture with your hands, all that can help, but mostly because the mind is surprisingly hard to still, especially after a lifetime of constant activity. I can’t recommend any specific practices, but I personally just sit somewhere quiet while withdrawing from my surroundings, focusing on my thoughts and really realizing that I am not my thoughts/feelings/mind and grounding myself.
>But wouldn’t the Deity be the One (panentheism)?
Yes. The creator deity would be the one, because nothing can exist apart from the one. The One alone is, everything else derives its very existence from it, this is what is meant in Buddhism when the world is said to be void and “empty”, it is empty of inherent existence, it does not exist of itself, but provisionally and from the ultimate reality which creates, sustains and destroys it. It is recognizing and realizing this reality that is paramount. Stopping at a creator deity is better than something like crude animism/polytheism, but it’s not the peak of the mountain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14494742
>If God is indistinguishable from the Universe, how can he be a distinct being with desires and agency
God, and by God I mean the ultimate reality/ground of being, the One etc., is not just the sum total of everything in the universe. That is pantheism, as the denial of God’s transcendence is what distinguishes pantheism from other forms of theism. This notion is not compatible with divine simplicity, because if God is absolutely without parts, then God can’t be equivalent to the material universe. What is meant by divine simplicity is that God is Being Itself, the Upanishads describe Brahman as Being/Consciousness/Bliss, this is the essential nature of God and not attributes that he exemplifies. God alone exists, all else “borrows” existence from God and has no inherent existence. God is not a “distinct being” alongside other objects in the cosmos, God is being itself, from which the cosmos temporarily borrows being. How can God have desires, for what could God possibly desire? Desire implies a deficiency, and a God with desires is a deficient deity who lacks something.

Reading through these "battles" it's pretty much always hundreds of Chinese ships and tens of thousands of Chinese soldiers versus like... 6 European ships at most, with most of the European "combatants" being sailors rather than soldiers. The "Dutch fleet" was actually a Dutch trading company, and the "Portuguese fleet" was actually a diplomatic envoy sent to establish a trading post at Guangzhou, and was not even armed with any heavy cannon because they weren't expecting to be ambushed by an army 50x their size when they arrived. Even then they lost only 2 of their 6 ships and less than 50 sailors before managing to escape. Ming China proclaimed this a great victory over the mostly unarmed traders of Portugal, hence dubbed "the barbarian fleet".

Even funnier is that pretty much all of these naval battles were situations where the Chinese attacked Europeans without warning then claimed victory after vanquishing an enemy with a fraction of their own number. Only Russia was different, because it was a case of China and Russia squabbling over control of a region that was on both their borders. Russia scouted it and established a fort, then China attacked the fort several times to force the Russian expedition to leave. I'll give the Chinese credit for this, they "only" outnumbered the Russians 3000 to 2000, a landmark in Chinese-western conflict, though it came at the cost of several hundred Chinese soldiers' lives since they did not outnumber the enemy 10-1 as normal.

posts.com: I think the limitation of the turtle ship was its effective range. You have to give over a lot of storage space for powder and shot, so you wouldn't have the provisions for a lengthy journey. It's a ship perfectly designed to defend the coastline and inlets of a peninsula besieged by a foreign invader from the sea. So for Europe, I think it could've probably changed the course of history for any of a few different island nations. Syracuse, for example, might've been able to hold the Romans off indefinitely with these ships, but with gunpowder in the mix, and the Roman propensity for adaptation, I wouldn't bet against team Roma.

>The lorcha is a type of sailing vessel having a junk rig with a Cantonese or other Chinese-style batten sails on a Portuguese or other European-style hull. The hull structure made the lorcha faster and able to carry more cargo than the normal junk. The advantage of the junk rig was in its ease of handling and resulting reduced crewing requirement, together with its relatively low cost of construction. Owing to its simplicity, it was also easier to repair. Lorchas were made locally of camphor or teak and generally were of 30 to 150 tons burthen.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hongyipao#Chinese_improvements

>Chinese gunsmiths continued to modify "red barbarian" cannons after they entered the Ming arsenal, and eventually improved upon them by applying native casting techniques to their design. In 1642, Ming foundries merged their own casting technology with European cannon designs to create a distinctive cannon known as the "Dingliao grand general." Through combining the advanced cast-iron technique of southern China and the iron-bronze composite barrels invented in northern China, the Dingliao grand general cannons exemplified the best of both iron and bronze cannon designs. Unlike traditional iron and bronze cannons, the Dingliao grand general's inner barrel was made of iron, while the exterior of brass.[1][12]

>The resulting bronze-iron composite cannons were superior to iron or bronze cannons in many respects. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14492209
>1 Timothy uses words that Paul literally never uses anywhere else
Paul used an amanuensis to write some of his epistles, so differences such as this can arise due to this, e.g. Rom. 16:22 "I, Tertius, who wrote this epistle, greet you in the Lord." Moreover this is a speculative argument; people can write in different way at different times for different purposes in different styles. It can't prove anything.
>It discusses church practices that weren't common during Paul's lifetime
This is begging the question. Firstly you don't actually have proof that the church offices were not functioning in this manner near the end of Paul's life. 1 Tim also does show less development than what is witnessed later by Ignatius, e.g. a separate office of bishop.
>It's not included in early Bibles and was not grouped with Paul's other letters
Such as Marcion, and the reason he did not include them is, again, speculation. Tertullion claims he rejected them for theological reasons, or perhaps he simply did not know them. There is no way to know.
>and it wasn't written by Paul, then why would it be binding?
That is certainly where this argument is designed to go.

The invention of the internet accelerated that massively which is why atheism has been increasing sharply since the 90s. Even extremely conservative regions like the Middle East are seeing a decline in religion due to the internet. The only places where it hasn’t started to decline are in places like sub-Saharan Africa where most people live in poor rural communities without internet access, and in communities like the Amish who almost completely shut themselves out from the modern world. The decline of religion and corresponding rise of atheism has always been inevitable since society would eventually progress to a point of being largely interconnected.

The US did help kick start the Western European economy with the Marshall Plan as a measure to contain the spread of communism. Leftists viewed the US as a degenerate self absorbed pampered society. posts.com: Though I was born before the War, during the post-war years, I was still a child. My views of the world during the time in question are, therefore very limited to the narrow world of a ranch kid just starting to school. Before public school, we children regarded any trip into town a treat. If it was a Saturday, we would get a haircut and be able to attend the Saturday Matinee. Newsreel, a couple of cartoons, a Johnny Mack Brown Serial, and a "B" picture. There was no rating system, but then film censorship cast a decided chill over Hollywood. Disney produced a wonderful documentary, "The Living Desert", but children werent allowed to see it because some furry little animal gave birth to a litter ... on film. Even at a tender age that struck me as ludicrous. As rancher I was already helping brand, castrate, ear cut, and vaccinate calves. I remember thinking City kids must be soft, or soft-headed; probably never rode a horse in their lives.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14493189
Innocent yes though I realize this is subjective. My Mam was born on the family plantation during, or shortly after the Civil War. Her family was decimated, but her Tather survived and became responsible for a number of young orphans.

Socially there were two theaters in town, but we preferred the Grand. For adults on weekends, there were drawings for house wares, grocery staples, and other boring stuff. The evening show still had the newsreel, but maybe only one cartoon before the "A" Picture. We got to see movies perhaps a couple of dozen times a year. Mostly we listened to the radio. Radio was a transition between Vaudeville and television. Bob Hope and Red Skelton polished their acts on one and two night stands on long road trips, and then got to settle down in front of a microphone. Juggling Acts didn't do so well. The situation comedy was born and families would gather around the radio for a half hour of laughter. The radio brought us the war news, and the adults were constantly trying to figure out for sure where Jimmy Stewart was serving, and how dangerous it might be. Radio was a practical thing to, it gave the daily prices for beef, poultry and hog bellies. In town, women might listen to soap operas, or so we were told, but ranch women didn't have the time for such nonsense and besides the batteries powering the radio needed to be saved for when the men came just after dark.

We didn't run to any supermarket, because the nearest one was over thirty-five miles away. Staples were bought in bulk, and shirts were sewn on foot powered Singer Sewing Machines out of feed sacks. Fresh vegetables were grown in the Kitchen garden, and each plant watered by hand each day by the ranch kids. Gas ten cents per gallon!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Depends on the region. For people who already lived in large northern industrial cities, the present was sooty and dirty but otherwise manageable. Most people had homes and even if they had lost their retirement, total economic destruction didn't occur. The FDR economy was mediocre, and the auto industry had busted, but transportation was dirt cheap due to the glut of cars manufactured over the past twenty years. However there weren't a lot of places to drive them, which is how the rapidly expanding US Highway network came about. There was also the growing aviation industry, still young and not totally mature. For educated people there was many places needing employment, it was the rural and half-literate population that had trouble integrating into this new economy. The government was planning bigger, better regional industrial chains that would completely change how the country would operate.

Compare this to the South. The stock crash and Dust Bowl had completely wiped away much of northern Texas, communities erected there stopped existing. In central Nevada and eastern California, the Water Projects had successfully killed all the ranching by about this time. Newly aggressive Jim Crow laws and Mexico's Civil War meant huge waves of migration to the big cities, especially Los Angeles. People moving there in 1940 would live in slums but would witness the orchards be completely paved over and replaced with factories and later suburban housing.

Urbanization is a major key to all this as housing prices generally rose and real estate was a safe investment, war or not. This same generation would give rise to the boomers and, ultimately, cause America to become a predominantly urban country around 1975 in time for the Bicentennial. And in terms of political coalitions, FDR's consensus more or less held until the Iranian Hostage Crisis in '79.

posts.sub: 800-year-old graves pinpoint where the Black Death began
posts.com:
>The Syriac engraving on the medieval tombstone was tantalizing: “This is the tomb of the believer Sanmaq. [He] died of pestilence.” Sanmaq, who was buried in 1338 near Lake Issyk Kul in what is now northern Kyrgyzstan, was one of many victims of the unnamed plague. By scrutinizing field notes and more photos from the Russian team that had excavated the graves in the 1880s, historian Philip Slavin found that at least 118 people from Sanmaq’s Central Asian trading community died in the epidemic.

>Slavin was on the trail of the origin of the Black Death, which devastated Europe a decade after the Kyrgyzstan burials. But he knew the medieval diagnosis of “pestilence” encompassed many horrific diseases. “I was almost 100% certain it was the beginning of the Black Death,” says Slavin, a medieval historian at the University of Stirling. “But there was no way to prove it without DNA.”

>Now, Slavin is senior author of a new study of ancient DNA from the “pestilence” victims showing they were indeed infected with the bacterium, Yersinia pestis, that caused the Black Death. The strain that killed them was ancestral to all the strains that rampaged across Europe a decade later and continued to kill for the next 500 years. The bacterium jumped from rodents to humans just before the Kyrgyzstan burials, perhaps after sudden changes in rainfall or temperature, the researchers propose
